text: In Problem 2.2, students scale ratios to solve problems. The ratios in Problem 2.2 are rates. Each ratio/rate compares two quantities measured in different units, number of pizzas and price in dollars. This is not the first time students have used rates, but it is the first time the word has been explicitly defined. Student also used rate tables in the Grade 6 unit, Comparing Quantities.

While using rate tables to compare pizza prices at two different pizzerias. The pizza prices foreshadow the introduction of the “constant of proportionality,” which is introduced in Problem 2.3. Students find patterns within a rate table contrasting two different situations, one of which is proportional and the other is not. Students will need to determine the impact of a delivery charge being added to the price of pizzas from one company. Presenting students with a non-proportional situation allows students to compare and contrast to a proportional situation. This makes it more explicit how to describe a proportional relationship.

Implementation Note: Be sure to hold a discussion after the Initial Challenge before moving on to the What If. This will allow you to highlight your students’ strategies before analyzing the strategies of other students that are presented in the What If. You can use the strategies in the What If to connect to how your students thought about the proportional and non-proportional costs when making the tables.

Have students work on the Initial Challenge. As the groups finish, have them look at the What If questions and compare their thinking and strategies to the students in the What If. This may allow a discussion of strategies different from students’ own thinking for solving the Initial Challenge.
Build on understanding of ratios and their usefulness to make comparisons. Deepen understanding that a rate is the comparison of two quantities measured in different units.
Explore situations that require recognizing and analyzing proportional relationships to solve problems. Find and use unit rates, scaling, and equivalent ratios.
Begin to think about when a situation is not proportional, e.g. cannot be represented by equivalent ratios.
How can you determine if a situation is proportional?
Use Learning Aid 2.2: Royal and Howdy’s Pizza Costs to discuss the comparison statements in the Introduction.
• Comparisons have two quantities. What are the two quantities in each statement? (number of pizzas and cost)
If you did not introduce the term and description of a rate in the Summarize of Problem 2.1, introduce the term now.

• Since each ratio is a comparison of two quantities measured in different units (pizza and tables), they are called rates. Can you think of other rates (comparisons with different units that would not combine to a part to whole ratio) that we have used? (Answers will vary. Investigation 1 examples include number of batches and number of 1 cup servings, or the words Mitch can read in hour. In Grade 6 Comparing Quantities examples included cupcakes and cost, Chewy Fruit Worms sold and amount of money collected, ounces of kernels and cups of popcorn, time and distance traveled.)
Use Teaching Aid 2.2: Introduction to review the rate table and proportion strategies in the Introduction. These strategies review finding the number of pizzas for 210 people in the previous Problem.
Tony’s Rate Table: To find the number of pizzas for 210 people.
Students might use what they know about multiples and scale up from 30 people to 210 people.
Students might combine the ratios of 200 people get 80 pizzas and 10 people get 4 pizzas to find that 210 people get 84 pizzas.
Students might use what they know about multiples and scale up from 10 people to 210 people.
Selma’s Proportion: To find the number of pizzas for 210 people.

For the Initial Challenge, have students keep their books closed or keep them from looking at the What If. The What If presents student strategies that you may not want students to see until after working on the tables with pizzas.

Introduce the Royal Pizza and Howdy’s Pizza deals using Learning Aid 2.2: Royal and Howdy’s Pizza Costs. You will want one Learning Aid per student to optimize class time. Tell students that Royal Pizza and Howdy’s Pizza are advertising their prices. Students need to notice the different costs for the different amounts of pizza.

• We are considering buying pizza for a class celebration. I found adds from two pizzerias. What do you notice and what do you wonder? (Answer will vary. Students may wonder and notice things about the names of the pizzerias, the quality of the pizzas, the price for different numbers of pizzas, what the toppings might be or cost, and the delivery charges.)
Have students work with a partner on this Problem.
